So before we start learning some alternative 
phrases it's important to note and to think

about the culture of Britain, so in the UK we do 
have a culture of politeness, we very much like

to apologize and you've probably seen examples 
of this in movies and TV series that you watch.

For example, if someone bumps into you if you're 
walking in the street or on the train you will

probably apologize to that person, so they 
might apologize to you for bumping into you

but we have this culture of politeness and what 
we tend to do is just apologize for everything,
even when it's not our fault.

So if you've made a mistake it's 
important to own up to that mistake

and all you can say is "I made 
a mistake" or "My mistake."

This way you are owning up to the fact that you 
made a mistake and you are apologizing for it.

More simply you could even say 
"I apologize" or "my apologies."

So if you've made a mistake and you really 
want to emphasize how sorry you are,

you could say "I'm ever so sorry," so 
this is really showing that you deeply

regret what happened or you deeply 
apologize for what has happened.

You could also say "I want to apologize to..." if 
you want to apologize to someone, so to a person,

or you could say "I want to 
apologize for (something)"

So if there's a particular thing that you 
want to apologize for, then you would say

"I apologize for being late," for example.
And if you want to apologize to a person you

would say "I want to apologize to you," 
or you could say "I want to apologize

to my friend because I made a mistake."
Another great phrase that you can use

when you want to own up to something, 
you could say "I owe you an apology."

So that's showing someone that you've made 
a mistake and that you're owning up to it

and that you feel that it's necessary 
to say sorry to them and to apologize.

One that you can use maybe when you're 
having a discussion with someone about

a disagreement or something that happened and 
you see that you were wrong in that situation,

you can simply say "I was wrong," and again this 
is another way of saying that you are sorry.

One that sounds a little bit more dramatic 
is "I hope you can forgive me," so

this is kind of putting it on the other person and 
saying "I am sorry but I hope you can forgive me,

I hope we can move on from this," so you might 
have heard this more in TV series and movies maybe

when someone has broken up with someone or when 
someone has maybe cheated on the other person,

or maybe something not as serious as that 
as well. Maybe someone made a mistake with

a friend and they are feeling guilty 
or they are feeling bad about it,

they might say to them "I 
hope you can forgive me."

And you could simply say "Forgive me."
So this sometimes can sound a bit

desperate so be careful when to use it, you 
don't want to use this one all the time,

because it kind of makes people think that you've 
done something really wrong that they must forgive

you for and by saying forgive me it sounds a 
bit desperate, so don't use this one too much.

One that you can probably use in the 
workplace maybe if you've made a mistake,

you know you lost sight of something and you're 
speaking to your boss about it you could say "It

won't happen again," so this is confirming 
that you acknowledge that you made a mistake

and you are telling them that it won't happen 
again, you won't make the same mistake again.

maybe a group of you are 
being reprimanded or told off

for something and you want to own up that it 
was your fault, you can say "It's my fault."

So you are taking responsibility for 
your actions and for what has happened.

Okay so now we're going to take a look at some 
more formal phrases or expressions that you can

use instead of saying "I'm sorry," and most of 
these would probably be used more in the workplace

or with people that you're 
not really that familiar with.

So you wouldn't use these with friends 
but you would use it when you want to be

a bit more professional or more polite with 
people that you don't really know that well.

So the first one is "I take full 
responsibility." "I take full

responsibility for my behavior," you could say.
So again this is taking ownership of the fact that

you've made a mistake that something is your 
fault and you are taking full responsibility.

Again, if you've really 
made a mistake you might say

"It was wrong of me." So you know you're 
kind of reflecting now you've seen that

maybe you made a mistake and you are owning up 
to the fact that you were wrong in this case.

If you're in a situation where you've made a 
mistake but you should have seen it coming or

you should have thought in that moment to avoid it 
happening you could say "It was careless of me."

So if you are careless it means that 
you're not taking care in a situation,

so maybe you weren't really thinking in 
that moment and you made a mistake, whereas

if you had thought about it -if you were more 
careful- then you wouldn't be in this situation.

So the next one is very formal. 
It's "I sincerely apologize."

So you probably might write this, 
rather than say it like you could say it

maybe if you're in the workplace and you've 
made a mistake and you really want to show

how sincere you are, how much you mean you are 
sorry, you would say "I sincerely apologize."

You might also see this written in 
letters or in emails, for example,

maybe if someone has made a mistake, maybe 
a company that you've been working with

has made a mistake and they would want 
to show you how much they are sorry

that they made this mistake, so they 
would use "sincerely" to do that.

Another way to show that you have 
reflected about what has happened

and that you are extremely sorry 
you could say "I deeply regret."

a mistake is to say "I messed up."

So instead of saying my bad you could
